FRS_Method: GPS CARRIER PHASE STATIC RELATIVE POSITION

_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Tank, Pressure Valve, Level Gauge, Piping Valves
_prev_prog_3.Description: The PTI Sumter facility is located in the Sumter Industrial Park. The land use zoning for the facility is Heavy Industrial. The facility is bordered by the CSX Railroad, Cains Mill Road and Yuasa/Exide Batteries Inc. The facility was built by Exide in 1965 and was purchased by CP Chemicals now Phibro-Tech in 1976. Phibro-Tech manufactures printed circuit board etchants and recovers Copper in returned spent etchants to be regenerated which is then used in agricultural fungicides. Potential significant receptor pointsin case of an accident would be Pocalla Springs Elementary School which is 1.5 miles from Phibro-Tech. Sumter 1.5 miles. A long-term health care facility is located around .5 miles away. Furman Middle School is around 2 miles from the site.Kingsberry Middle School ia about 2 miles from the site.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
PHIBRO-TECH, INC.
SUMTER, SOUTH CAROLINA

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY


Introduction
Phibro-Tech, inc. (PTI) is located approximately 4.0 miles south of the city limits of Sumter, South Carolina in the Sumter Industrial Park off U.S. Highway 15.  PTI's facility encompasses about 58 acres.  The manufacturing facility encompasses about 11 acres at the southern end of the property.  PTI is committed to the safety and well being of its employees, neighboring community, and the environment.  PTI is an active member in the Sumter County Chamber of Commerce Environmental Group and the South Carolina Occupational Safety Council.  The chemical that this report will deal with is Anhydrous Ammonia.  PTI's policy is to implement reasonable measures to prevent the release of hazardous materials from occurring, to provide early detection of a release in the unlikely event that one would occur, and to have a contingency plan to respond promptly and safely to such a release. 

Regulated Substance
This Risk Management Plan (RMP) has been prepared to address the following regulated substance at the PTI facility.

    Anhydrous Ammonia

Anhydrous Ammonia is received from LaRoche Industries Inc., Naperville, IL in tank trucks.  PTI has a 12,000 gallon ammonia tank at the facility that is leased from LaRoche Industries Inc.

Worst Case & Alternate Scenarios
The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has defined the Worst Case Scenario as the hypothetical rupture and full release of all the contents of the facilities largest storage vessel in 10 minutes, assuming all safeguards have failed , during extremely stable weather conditions.  Our scenario would involve an 80%  full 12,000 gallon tank of Anhydrous Ammonia (9600 gallons or 50,000lbs.).
The EPA has also specified in the RMP rule that each facility define a specific Alternate or Realistic Scenario that could also have off site impact, based on plant operations.  The realistic scenarios are to be modeled using the actual active and passive mitiga

tion systems that are in place if they are capable of withstanding the event that triggered the release during typical weather conditions.  The realistic scenario selected and modeled for anhydrous ammonia was the release that resulted from a broken feed line from the storage tank to the process.

Accidental Release Prevention Program
PTI has a comprehensive release prevention program.  PTI has in place, physical safeguards to prevent a release of anhydrous ammonia.  PTI also follows best industrial practices for the design and construction of equipment, piping and instrumentation.  Our process design includes excess flow valves, safety release valves, and ammonia sensors.

Five Year Release History
PTI has not had an accident in the last five years.

Emergency Response
PTI has a comprehensive emergency response program that includes detection alarms, emergency shut down procedures, excess flow valves, and a scrubbing system.  In the event the release can not be controlled completely by these systems, PTI has an Emergency Response Team trained and equipped to respond safely to a release in accordance with a written Emergency Response Plan.  


Safety Improvements
 PTI has ammonia sensors two ammonia sensors located north and south of the ammonia tank. The sensors trigger an alarm to let the operators know that there is a release in progress and that the EmergencyRresponse Plan needs to be activated

Y2K Sensitivity
PTI is aware and sensitive to the "Year 2000" software issue.  Our process and equipment has been surveyed for compliance with good results.  There were no concerns identified.  The Sunter facility will be closed and all processes secured on the evening of December 31, 1999 and January 1, 2000.  PTI will conduct a pre-startup safety review prior to the next operating day.
